Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Controlling Chemo-Mechanical Properties of Metal Coordinating Polymer and Inorganic Nanoparticle Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605943/1605699
Holten-Andersen, Niels/Tracy, Joseph B.

Interfaces between metal coordinating proteins and inorganic surfaces have a vital role in the mechanical properties of some of the most remarkable composites found in nature. From the underwater adhesive glues of mussels to the tough shells of nacre, sticky interactions between metal binding proteins and inorganic surfaces have increasingly been found to control their mechanical properties. A simpler, synthetic system, where inorganic nanoparticles serve as dynamic bridges for metal binding polymers, will be investigated to learn principles of composite material design from nature and to apply these principles for engineering new materials with controlled and responsive mechanical properties. Potential applications for these materials include drug delivery, self-healing composites, and 3D printing. The PIs will develop learning modules based on these bio-inspired composites for use in outreach activities to increase public awareness about nanotechnology and to recruit more students into STEM careers.

The goal of this project is to utilize bio-inspired metal coordinating polymer-nanoparticle (MCP-NP) composites as model systems for understanding how to engineer novel mechanics via controlled MCP-NP interfacial dynamics. In contrast to previous MCP materials with metal ion crosslinkers, NPs will serve as supramolecular crosslinkers, with a tunable number of ligands bound per NP. Chemical and physical parameters of the system will be adjusted to obtain a fundamental understanding of how molecular interactions at MCP-NP interfaces affect the bulk mechanical properties of MCP-NP composites and to demonstrate control over the mechanical response. In comparison with traditional engineering composites and other composite hydrogels, MCP-NP composites are viscoelastic and have tunable interfacial bonding. Magnetically and optically responsive NPs have been selected to also allow remote heating using light and magnetic fields. This project will provide a deeper understanding of composite interfacial dynamics critical for improved engineering of composite mechanical properties, such as self-healing and tunable fluid-solid transitions. Insights about the relationship between chemistry at MCP-NP interfaces and the mechanical response will be applicable to other composite systems with dynamic interfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In nature, dynamic interfaces between metal binding proteins and inorganic surfaces have a key role in controlling composite material mechanics. Yet the dynamic mechanical properties of synthetic composites composed of metal binding polymers and inorganic nanoparticles had scarcely been studied prior to this project. The concept underpinning this project was therefore to use nanoparticles as dynamic crosslinking structures in metal binding polymer hydrogels, because their versatile surface chemistry and size-controlled number of crosslinking sites per nanoparticle were predicted to impart novel, controllable mechanical properties to the resulting hydrogel composites. By characterizing and understanding how such soft composite mechanics are determined by polymer-nanoparticle interfacial dynamics, the new knowledge generated in this project has brought us closer to the design of composite materials with novel responsive mechanical properties when stimulated with magnetic fields and light.

 

Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project was to utilize bioinspired metal binding polymer-nanoparticle composites as model systems for understanding how to engineer novel composite mechanics by controlling polymer-particle interfacial dynamics. The first objective was to correlate the polymer-particle bond energy with binding chemistry. Via selection of metal binding ligand and nanoparticle composition, we examined a wide range of interfacial ligand-particle bond energies accessible via bio-inspired binding chemistry in composite gels. Measurements elucidated how the bond energy of ligand-particle crosslinks changed as a function of the physical-chemical environment at the interface (ligand and nanoparticle design, pH, and temperature). This approach has enabled the programmable assembly of highly anisotropic nanoparticle hydrogels with tunable percolation thresholds. The second objective was to control bulk composite mechanics via polymer-particle dynamics. Rheology was used to characterize how polymer-particle interfacial structure and dynamics influence global network viscoelastic mechanics. By tuning the polymer-particle interfacial binding strength and controlling particle concentrations and size, we demonstrated an unprecedented level of control over bulk composite gel mechanics. For example, this approach provided access to new multi-scale material mechanics with energy-dissipative structural dynamics tunable on multiple length and time scales, which allowed us to take important steps towards breaking the traditional compromise between material stiffness and rate of self-healing in dynamically crosslinked polymer materials.

 

Broader Impacts: Fundamental insights gained from this project have taught us how to engineer hydrogel composite mechanics via polymer-particle interfacial chemistry. This knowledge has been applied by other research groups in the engineering of other classes of materials, where stimuli-responsive dynamic properties are desired, for example, in remote-controlled self-healing and actuated soft materials. Finally, themes and results from our research were integrated into our education and outreach activities. Specifically, Holten-Andersen developed a class on "(Bio)-Inspired Polymer Engineering," which helped stimulate interest in biological and bioinspired materials, while at the same time providing a unique opportunity for curious minds to learn about cutting-edge research. Tracy and his research group, in partnership with the NCSU College of Education, developed and performed demonstrations on the synthesis of properties of nanoparticles for K-12 students and developed and disseminated instructional materials and hands-on activities for teachers on biomaterials.


Last Modified: 03/08/2021
Modified by: Niels Holten-Andersen

By characterizing and understanding how such soft composite mechanics are determined by polymer-nanoparticle interfacial dynamics, the new knowledge generated in this project has brought us closer to the design of composite materials with novel responsive mechanical properties when stimulated with magnetic fields and light. Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project was to utilize bioinspired metal binding polymer-nanoparticle composites as model systems for understanding how to engineer novel composite mechanics by controlling polymer-particle interfacial dynamics.
